fields.physical_description:
Tracy catalogue entry (#298)
Chest; of hutch-type construction, the front is formed of a single plain panel set in broad stiles slightly shaped below; the back is of similar construction to the front and united to it at either end by a bar, behind which are the single panels which form the sides. The top, of pine, of 18th century date, is probably a reproduction of the original; it is hinged by means of pivots inserted horizontally through the back uprights and fixed into the clamps on the underside of the lid.

The piece is of rough workmanship saw marks being clearly visible on the front panel.

Notes made for RFS store visit, Nick Humphrey
Repairs
Both rear feet (and one front) tipped.
Rat hole at rear
Lid replaced but following form of original (with battens on underside at each end) and apparently using earlier fixings - huge iron pin hinges (?); the original lid presumably had a clasp for ring fixing on the front. A trace of an iron hinge at PL rear.

The wide leg-stiles produced by cleaved oak to centre of trunk (quarter riven).
The front and back (saw marked) panels held in a long groove, held by 4/5 pegs at each end (round, relatively tight fitting). The front and back panels are remarkably thin given the difficulty of pit-sawing so thinly.
The ends fit into a tall mortise and held by 3 long pegs.
The two end battens tenoned into the front and back planks - served to hold it together.
The bottom (a single plank, now split and wormy) held poorly with nails through the ends into the ends of the planks, and through the front (note iron staining) - but also from a comparitively early date by two metal U shaped brackets. Note old nails in bottom (for an old patch?)

Both locks attached plausibly with clinched nails

RPs record that it was bought (£5.10.0) from E.M.Dent who bought it in 1919 from a dealer, and that it was formerly in Great Bedwyn Church (but without any further detail or substantiation.)
fields.dimensions: Height: 63.5 cm, Width: 128 cm, Depth: 54 cm
fields.materials_techniques: Oak, riven and sawn; hutch-type construction
fields.bibliography:
Charles Tracy, English Medieval Furniture and Woodwork (London, The Victoria and Albert Museum, 1988), cat. no.298
CESCINSKY, Herbert & Ernest Gribble: Early English Furniture & Woodwork. Vols. I & II. (London, 1922), p.2, fig.1
fields.history_note:
From Great Bedwyn Church, Wiltshire (information from vendor).

CESCINSKY, Herbert & Ernest Gribble: Early English Furniture & Woodwork. Vols. I & II. (London, 1922), p.1 illustrate this chest: 'The earliest chests of which we have any knowledge date from the middle thirteenth century. The tops nearly always open on pin-hinges, that is, on two pins fixed at the ends of the back under-clamp of the top and socketed into the uprights of the sides. These are rarely, if ever, found in the fourteenth century, heavy iron clamp-hinges being substituted...There is no attempt at ornamentation, altough, originally, the bottom of the upright styles may have been carved with simple cusping. The ironwork at present on the chest is all of a much later date.'
fields.historical_context_note: Great Bedwyn Church probably dates from c.1092, on the remains of a Saxon building. The chancel and nave probably date to c.1220. The north transept dates to c.1320 and the tower c1350-1400. The south transept was retored 1853-5. In 1854 the timber screen (thought to date from the 14th century) was removed from its original position between the chancel and the crossing, and displayed at the V&A 1919-46, then redisplayed in the church (rededicated 1975).
